unnormalised: **Question:** What's the deal with all these festivals in India? Seriously, there's like, one every week!
normalised: **Question:** What is the deal with all these festivals in India? Seriously, there is like, one every week!

unnormalised: Okay, lemme tell you, trying to keep track of Indian festivals is harder than trying to parallel park an auto-rickshaw in peak hour traffic on Linking Road. Seriously, *every other day* it feels like there's another public holiday. My boss, Mr. Sharma, nearly had a coronary when I asked for leave on 25/12! He goes, "Diwali was just last month, and now Christmas? What next, Bhai Dooj in July?"
normalised: Okay, let me tell you, trying to keep track of Indian festivals is harder than trying to parallel park an auto-rickshaw in peak hour traffic on Linking Road. Seriously, every other day it feels like there is another public holiday. My boss, Mister Sharma, nearly had a coronary when I asked for leave on twenty fifth december! He goes, "Diwali was just last month, and now Christmas? What next, Bhai Dooj in July?"

unnormalised: And the sheer variety! It's not just Diwali, Holi, Eid. We've got Teej, Pongal, Onam, Durga Puja… the list is longer than my mother-in-law's shopping list for Deepavali! And don't even get me started on trying to understand *why* we celebrate some of them. Something about a demon king being defeated, maybe a harvest, or just an excuse for everyone to eat sweets for 3 days straight. My brain cells can't handle it.

Something about a demon king being defeated, maybe a harvest, or just an excuse for everyone to eat sweets for three days straight. My brain cells can not handle it.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole issue of dates. You'd think with calendars being invented, everyone would be on the same page. Nope. Some festivals follow the lunar calendar, some the solar, some follow Aunty Kamala's handwritten notes from 1952. Seriously, you need a PhD in Vedic astrology to figure out when Ganesh Chaturthi actually is. One year, it was on 19/09, the next it's on 08/09...who knows what 2025 will bring!

One year, it was on nineteenth september, the next it is on eighth september...who knows what two thousand and twenty five will bring!

unnormalised: And the amount of prep! Cleaning the entire house for Diwali is practically a national sport. It's like the Olympics of domestic chores. My wife starts planning 6 months in advance. “The paint, Rakesh, *must* be completed by 10/10 at the latest. And the mithai order… from Haldiram’s, of course!” And the shopping! Oh god, the shopping. Every festival is an excuse to buy a new saree, new electronics, new car... new everything! My credit card weeps quietly in the corner.

Oh god, the shopping. Every festival is an excuse to buy a new saree, new electronics, new car... new everything! My credit card weeps quietly in the corner.

unnormalised: But honestly? Amidst all the chaos, the confusion, and the slight financial ruin, I wouldn’t trade it for anything. The sheer joy, the colours, the food (oh god, the food!), the family gatherings… it’s what makes India, well, India. Even though I can never remember which god we’re worshipping on what day (was that Vishnu or Shiva last Tuesday?), I know I’m surrounded by love, laughter, and enough mithai to send me into a sugar coma till next year’s Lohri on 13/01.
